thread.title: Manta rays off WA coast buck worldwide trend of decline
thread.title_full: Manta rays off WA coast buck worldwide trend of decline

title: Manta rays off WA coast buck worldwide trend of decline
text:
Map: Cocos (Keeling) Islands 
A decade of research by a Queensland university has found links between sustainable fishing practices and an increase in the population of manta rays in north-west Western Australia. 
The University of Queensland (UQ) started Project Manta in 2007 because there was such a shortage of scientific knowledge of the manta rays' basic biology and ecology. 
Ten years of data has revealed populations of oceanic mantas around Exmouth and Coral Bay are bucking a worldwide trend of decline of the species. 
According to the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN), there has been over an 80 per cent drop in manta ray populations around the world due to targeted fishery. Photo: Manta ray numbers off WA's coast are increasing, bucking a worldwide trend of decline (Supplied: Karen Willshaw) 
They IUCN claims manta rays are fished in unsustainable numbers globally due to an Asian medicinal market built on the belief that gill rakers — filters used by the ray to separate water from food — have healing properties. 
However, Project Manta researcher and UQ PhD candidate Asia Armstrong said they had found that more than 800 manta rays frequenting the Ningaloo coastline. 
"Luckily, in Australian waters manta rays do not have too much pressure put on them in terms of fisheries," Ms Armstrong said. 
"But in other parts of the world, they are actually targeted for their gill rakers." Citizen scientist turns hobby into research 
Photographer and Cocos Keeling Island resident Karen Willshaw has jumped on board as a citizen scientist for the project. 
She has taken hundreds of manta ray photographs over a decade and said the bellies of the rays were how they were identified. Photo: Citizen scientist Karen Willshaw photographs manta ray populations in the Indian Ocean Territories as a citizen scientist. (Supplied: Karen Willshaw) 
"Out of all of the images I have sent [to Ms Armstrong], all the belly shots, she was able to identify 35 individuals," Ms Willshaw said. 
"I do ask our divers, if you do get belly shots please let me have a copy so I can send it to Project Manta. 
"If not, just tell me the same manta has been seen regularly or 'wow, we've got a new manta'." 
Ms Willshaw said when taking photos, she had to look at the spots on the manta's belly — in a similar way a zebra or giraffe is identified, every ray has unique markings. 
"It's like our thumb print; no two thumb prints are the same [and basically a Manta belly [is] their thumb print, their individuality," she said. 
"These creatures need protecting and if my photography can help science then I'm all for it."
